metadata.case_name: Ilindra Bhaskaracharyulu Gupta & J. Pandurangarao v. Andhra Pradesh Public Service Commission & Anr.
metadata.case_number: Petition No. 355 of 1961 and No. 1 of 1962

facts.text: Two petitions filed under Article 32 by Ilindra Bhaskaracharyulu Gupta (No. 355/1961) and J. Pandurangarao (No. 1/1962) challenging validity of rule framed by Governor of Andhra under Articles 234 and 309 proviso for Andhra Judicial Service.
J. Pandurangarao belongs to family settled in Guntur district, Andhra Pradesh for generations; born, brought up, educated there.
Pandurangarao passed B.A. from Andhra Christian College, Guntur in 1950; L.L.B. from Nagpur University in 1952; enrolled as Advocate of Mysore High Court in 1954.
Practised as Advocate in Court at Tenali, Guntur district since enrolment.

Andhra Pradesh Public Service Commission (respondent No.1) invited applications for District Munsifs on 17th December 1960; para 4-A(1) required practising as Advocate of the High Court and 3 years actual practice in Courts of Civil or Criminal jurisdiction in India.
Pandurangarao applied on 27th January 1961; rejected on 25th September 1961 as not practising as Advocate of the Andhra High Court.
Notification required applications through High Court of Andhra Pradesh if practising in High Court, or through District Judge and High Court if in subordinate courts.
Impugned rule is Rule 12(b) prescribing for direct recruitment as District Munsif: practising as Advocate of the High Court and 3 years practice.
Under Andhra Bar Council Rule 1(ii), advocates from other High Courts can practise in Andhra High Court on reciprocity, subject to provisos.
Public Service Commission conducted tests for candidates, including petitioners' cases considered.

legal_issues.text: What does 'the High Court' mean in Rule 12(b) and notification para 4-A(1): any High Court or the Andhra High Court?
If 'the High Court' means Andhra High Court, does the rule violate Articles 14 and 16(1) by discriminating against advocates of other High Courts?

petitioner_arguments.text: Expression 'the High Court' in para 4-A(1) means any High Court in India, not specifically Andhra High Court.

Alternatively, if means Andhra High Court, rule is ultra vires as it contravenes Articles 14 and 16(1) by disqualifying advocates not of Andhra High Court, amounting to unconstitutional discrimination.

respondent_arguments.text: 'The High Court' means the Andhra High Court.
Rule valid as it ensures knowledge of local laws via practice as Andhra High Court advocate (apprenticeship, etc.); consider all rules together including age, education, language.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Nallanthighal Bhaktavatsalam Iyengar v. Secretary, Andhra PSC (AIR 1956 Andh 14)

respondent_arguments.text: Andhra HC advocates have attachment to institution and subject to its disciplinary jurisdiction, providing rational basis.

court_reasoning.text: 'The High Court' means Andhra High Court, as context is subordinate courts under Andhra HC; notification requires routing through Andhra HC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Definite article 'the' refers to particular Andhra High Court.

court_reasoning.text: Rule must satisfy Art 14 tests: intelligible differentia with nexus to object (suitable persons for judicial service, knowledge of local laws).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification based on enrolment in Andhra HC lacks rational nexus.

court_reasoning.text: Rule does not ensure local law knowledge: law degree covers it; reciprocity allows other HC advocates without local knowledge; better to prescribe exam.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No material shows requirement met by enrolment.

court_reasoning.text: Attachment/loyalty and disciplinary jurisdiction not relevant; all HC advocates share standards.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No nexus to judicial administration dedication.

court_reasoning.text: Rules considered individually; invalid rule not saved by valid others.
Andhra HC decision in Nallanthighal incorrect.

holdings.text: 'The High Court' in Rule 12(b) means Andhra High Court.
Rule 12(b) and corresponding notification clause ultra vires and unconstitutional under Article 14; no rational classification.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S.R. Tendolkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Tests for Article 14: intelligible differentia with nexus to object.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nallanthighal Bhaktavatsalam Iyengar v. Secretary, Andhra Public Service Commission

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for petitions; powers to frame rules; equality rights violated by rule.

statutes_cited.name: Andhra Judicial Service Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned rule prescribing qualifications for District Munsif; held ultra vires.

statutes_cited.name: Andhra Bar Council Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Allows reciprocity for advocates of other High Courts to practise in Andhra HC.

outcome.summary: Impugned Rule 12(b) and notification clause held ultra vires; directed Public Service Commission to entertain petitioners' applications and consider on merits without preliminary rejection; does not affect conducted tests.
outcome.relief_granted: Direction to entertain and process applications of petitioners and similar persons on merits.

key_quotes.text: In the context, the expression 'the High Court' must, we think, mean the Andhra High Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The impugned rule has introduced classification between one class of Advocates and the rest and the said classification must be said to be irrational inasmuch as there is no nexus between the basis of the said classification and the object intended to be achieved.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: All the High Courts have the same status all of them stand for the same high traditions of the Bar and the administration of justice.
key_quotes.speaker: court
